intro: Carphobolus cinereus, commonly known as the gray spurge, is a flowering plant native to North America. It is a member of the Euphorbiaceae family, characterized by its milky sap and unique floral structures. The plant typically grows in moist, disturbed soils and can be found in wetlands and along streambanks. Its leaves are alternate, ovate, and often have a silvery or grayish underside. The flowers are small and clustered in cyathia, which are modified inflorescences typical of the spurge family.
